citations.narrative:
There was insufficient distance and/or barriers between an animal and the public to assure the safety of the animal and/or
the public during a wallaby encounter at the facility on 5/30/23 (2 adults and 3 children). Two employees were present
during the encounter. The employee responsible for the white wallaby was on their phone and/or engaged in a
conversation with the second employee during part of the encounter (white wallaby was not being used in the encounter
but was in the exhibit space). The second employee responsible for the brown wallaby was standing next to the first staff
member and he/she stood several feet away from the brown wallaby and the 5 members of the public (the brown wallaby
was being used in the encounter). The 3 children surrounded the brown wallaby when it was up against one side of the
exhibit to offer the animal food (the upper body of at least one child was positioned above the head/body of the wallaby)
and the 3 children were also touching/petting the head and neck of the animal using their open hand and fingers. One of
the younger children offered the brown wallaby food while the child was in a crouched position next to the animal with
his/her head/face close to the mouth/head of the wallaby. The employees did not intervene during the wallaby interaction
when there was minimal distance between the children and the brown wallaby, and the employee standing several feet
away from the brown wallaby had no means of control of the wallaby during the interaction to ensure minimal risk of harm
to the wallaby and/or the public.
Per this Section, animals must be handled during public exhibition so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to
the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the public to assure the safety of animals and
the public. Lack of sufficient distance and/or control of an animal during public interactions poses a risk of harm to the
animals and/or the public. Correct by ensuring that employees present during animal interactions follow this requirement
to assure the safety of the animals and the public. Correct by 7/23/23.
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility representatives.
*END OF REPORT*
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
There was insufficient distance and/or barriers between an animal and the public to assure the safety of the animal and/or 
the public during a wallaby encounter at the facility on 5/30/23 (2 adults and 3 children). Two employees were present 
during the encounter. The employee responsible for the white wallaby was on their phone and/or engaged in a 
conversation with the second employee during part of the encounter (white wallaby was not being used in the encounter 
but was in the exhibit space). The second employee responsible for the brown wallaby was standing next to the first staff 
member and he/she stood several feet away from the brown wallaby and the 5 members of the public (the brown wallaby 
was being used in the encounter). The 3 children surrounded the brown wallaby when it was up against one side of the 
exhibit to offer the animal food (the upper body of at least one child was positioned above the head/body of the wallaby) 
and the 3 children were also touching/petting the head and neck of the animal using their open hand and fingers. One of 
the younger children offered the brown wallaby food while the child was in a crouched position next to the animal with 
his/her head/face close to the mouth/head of the wallaby. The employees did not intervene during the wallaby interaction 
when there was minimal distance between the children and the brown wallaby, and the employee standing several feet 
away from the brown wallaby had no means of control of the wallaby during the interaction to ensure minimal risk of harm 
to the wallaby and/or the public.  
 
Per this Section, animals must be handled during public exhibition so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to 
the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the public to assure the safety of animals and 
the public. Lack of sufficient distance and/or control of an animal during public interactions poses a risk of harm to the 
animals and/or the public. Correct by ensuring that employees present during animal interactions follow this requirement 
to assure the safety of the animals and the public. Correct by 7/23/23. 
 
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
*END OF REPORT* 
 
 n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
